awd_titl_txt: CPS:Synergy:Collaborative Research: Real-time Data Analytics for Energy Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Inadequate system understanding and inadequate situational awareness have caused large-scale power outages in the past.  With the increased reliance on variable energy supply sources, system understanding and situational awareness of a complex energy system become more challenging. This project leverages the power of big data analytics to directly improve system understanding and situational awareness. The research provides the methodology for detecting anomalous events in real-time, and therefore allow control centers to take appropriate control actions before minor events develop into major blackouts. The significance for the society and for the power industry is profound. Energy providers will be able to prevent large-scale power outages and reduce revenue losses, and customers will benefit from reliable energy delivery with service guarantees. Students, including women and underrepresented groups, will be trained for the future workforce in this area.

The project includes four major thrusts: 1) real-time anomaly detection from measurement data; 2) real-time event diagnosis and interpretation of changes in the state of the network; 3) real-time optimal control of the power grid; 4) scientific foundations underpinning cyber-physical systems. The major outcome of this project is practical solutions to event or fault detection and diagnosis in the power grid, as well as prediction and prevention of large-scale power outages.

por.por_cntn:
The award has allowed us to make great strides for detecting anomalous behavior on the power grid, evaluating failure risk, and to design control actions to prevent subsequent failures. We describe two accomplishment directions that, in our judgment, have the potential to significantly improve the state of knowledge and practice in the area of cyber physical systems. 

In one direction, we have developed the first first-principles model of stability-limited transmission line failure and developed new optimization techniques to limit such occurrences. The method employed ideas that were first used in quantum chemistry which allowed us to efficiently compute line failure probabilities. We demonstrated that the resulting risk of line failure matches very well with the observed failures from the western interconnect (the Bonneville Power Authority). Subsequently we developed an optimization method that allowed the control of electrical power in a way that reduced the probability faillure to a prescribed level. In particular, this addresses a standing challenge in reaching reliability-based decisions for the power grid. Reliability requirements are stated in probabilistic language ( average time -- the probability -- of load disconnect per customer per year) but current decisions frameworks cannot directly ensure that, they rely on indirect approaches called security constraints whose parameters are decided offlline to ensure enough reliability. Our ability to compute these probabilities and their derivatives allow to reach the prescribed reliability level precisely at the minimum cost in real time. 

Another exciting finding stemmed from our investigation of a fact observed empirically. That is, complicated optimal control problems with long time horizon seemed to be very well approximated with formulations with shorter horizon (and thus much easier to solve) provided the time horizons exhibited some overlap. In a series of publications we elucidated the analytical underpinning of this phenomenon and vastly generalized it. We showed that this phenomenon could be explained by a feature of such optimization problems that we call exponential decay of sensitivity. That is, for a time-indexed optimization problem, efffects of perturbations in the external data at a certain time on the solution at a different time decay exponentially with the distance between these times. Subsequently we generalized this concept to network indexed optimization problems and showed that the perturbation effects also decayed exponentially in space. In turn, this allows very efficiently solving such problems by domain decomposition with overlap -- fundamentally by multiple smaller local agents that need only limited information while getting an objective that is very close to the centralized solution. As a result the control problem can be solved much faster and with a much simpler communication structure. These findings have resulted in novel analysis tools for distributed control and hold the promise of elucidating further algorithmic patterns for large networked systems, and in particular for designing cheaper and more robust control algorithms.
